It doesn't matter if I raise less than 5 €, or surpass my goal amount by a thousand €,  please know that I cannot even express my gratitude to those who have taken the time to read about my artist residency in Ireland. Money is not the only way you can give, and you can help me raise the funds for this co-created adventure by sharing this campaign, and spreading the word to friends and family.

story:
Hey there! We are Cuddle or Die! 

A group of big-dream burners planning to bring a huge project out to the Black Rock desert. This is a camp born of the “if I want it, I should bring it” mentality that Burning Man thrives on. Over the last couple years the idea has grown and morphed into what is finally an achievable, yet still magnificent, theme camp that will enrich the burn for anyone who gets to play on our structures. There’s always ideas, especially out there, that are great and at their full extent would be incredible, but without the funding to achieve each goal the whole thing kinda falls flat. This could be one of those experiences. With your support, our three tall climbable structures, our fuzzy filled cuddle pit, and our 4500+ LEDs could easily be the best part of your burn, for the next several years (we have big expansion plans too!). But as our first year, we need your help to get it all started.

How does your contribution make -your- burn better?

At minimum we are aiming to cover three big expenses that are a bit more than we can bite off alone. The scaffolding to build the towers is amazingly expensive, and unsurprisingly quite heavy. This leads to a transportation issue. One of our biggest expenses that you can help with seems simple, getting it all out to the middle of nowhere. Next is power. Having over 4500 lights takes a hell of a lot more power than we have ever personally needed before, and generators are pricey. Especially the quiet ones that won’t annoy our neighbors all night so we can keep the lights on for you. This accounts for about ¾ of our goal.

The other quarter is to allow us to provide even more fun for you. Climbing scaffolding up to 13 feet is fun on it’s own, but what if you didn’t have to climb the actual scaffolding? What if you could climb a cargo net, or a rock wall, or show off your strength on a hanging rope, wouldn’t that be better? And instead of just a high energy playground, what if there were a couple hammocks lower in the front towers where you could rest in the shade without having to put much energy in? How about all those LEDs in the cuddle loft? Do you think it’d be more enjoyable with a layer of diffusing fabric to help cut down the harshness that LEDs can have? Have you ever wanted to try aerial silks? Or do want an aerial yoga class every morning throughout the week?  Did you answer yes to any of these questions? We did, too. That’s the other quarter of our goal. Enrichment. But how much we can provide all depends on you. In some ways this is a create-your-own adventure. How much fun do you want to have out there?

But what could go wrong?

With everything Burning Man, there are challenges. The environment, the wind, getting things out there, etc. But as mostly seasoned burners, none of these are new to us. We are working with a structural engineer and an architect to ensure some amount of safety in our structures. Sure safety third, but we want to ensure all the risks you are taking are ones you can control, not taking the risk that our towers might collapse at any given gust of wind.

While most of our members have been involved with theme camps in previous years, this is the first year that we’ve been responsible for running one, which is rather scary. It’s easy to dream big and not be realistic with what we can achieve out first year out, but with each step and idea we have we make three layers; minimum viable product, yeah that makes it cooler, and Holy shit that’d be awesome! Our internal funds can cover most of our minimal product, but who wants minimums at Burning Man? This is why we need your help. We don’t want to give you something half cocked.

Hey, that looks great, but I'm poor... Sorry :/

So maybe building your own infrastructure has taken every spare penny you have, we completely get that and don’t judge at all. We’ve got some members that need to make every cent count, too. There are other ways to help us though, if you are even half as excited about this idea as we are. Perhaps share this page with your burner family, there’s easy buttons above to help with that. Or perhaps you are a campless traveler and want somewhere to call home and you think our project is super rad and want to join us. Awesome! Send us an email about who you are. We still have a bit more space (placement was generous) to house a few adventurous cuddle-bugs.

No matter what you can do to help us, we are grateful for you positive energy and reading this far. We love you and please come get some cuddles during the week. Can’t wait to hug you!!

story:
I'm an artist based in Stroud in the UK who makes sculpture, installation and performative work which looks at memory and imagination, the self and the 'other'. I make large scale rammed earth pieces and large performative, participatory drawings, but recently have started a new body of work looking at how close imagination and memory are. I've been working with anthropologist and artist Elizabeth Hodson from the 'Knowing from the Inside' anthropology project led by Tim Ingold in Aberdeen and want to continue my research into memory, imagination and language.

Here's an example of some of my larger rammed earth work:

My new work has been influence by imaginings; miniature pen and ink drawings of imagined mountains and rock forms, small rammed earth mountain sculptures in unlikely places.

And now I have the amazing opportunity to travel the long way to Hyrynsalmi in Finland, to the sub-arctic circle, to spend a month in the snow, dark and wildness of the Oulu region. Here I will be able to work intensively on this new body of work; read and develop my ongoing research discussion with Dr Elizabeth Hodson and develop new performative work based on darkness/light, imagined fears and storytelling. 

This residency would give me time to reflect and work, to be immersed in an environment which would not only inspire new work but also which reflects my own making ethos. Mustarinda is an artist residency venue and ecological research centre (www.mustarinda.fi), they support low-carbon travel and encourage all artists in residence to travel by land and sea rather than fly. Travel is vital for my work, but I won't compromise my own decision made over 10 years ago not to fly. My family have traveled to several European residencies by train and boat and we know that not only is this way of travelling much better for the environment it also gives us a much deeper cultural understanding of the countries through which we travel. Moreover the work will start on the journey, with the collection of stories and interactions with people we meet along the way.

It's a long way... (map shows car route, we'll be traveling a similar route by train and ferry). 

My husband Ed and son Ru (6) are coming too... they will be informing the work I make and collaborating (when they're not doing their own work). They have come with me to residencies in the UK and Germany, they feed my creative practice and will, at Mustarinda, participate in the making process by sharing stories and fears. Ru is home-educated so travelling to Finland will be a massive learning experience for him and will feed his already busy imagination and contribute to his education. Here he is on the train back from Greece, busy writing and drawing in his travel journal.

So why fund this project? Any contribution you can make would enable us not only to get there in the first place but allow much more work to be made once there. And this work and research will be brought back and shown publically. Once I'm back in the UK I will have an exhibition of work made and present a talk about both the residency and the philosophy and anthropology research I'm involved in. This is not just a personal interest, the subjects and areas I'm researching are relevant to all (socially and politically), and there have been large audiences at previous talks and events I've organised so i know there are many eager for the chance to see and discuss more.

This project comes at a critical time in my practice, when a long body of work (over 10 years) is shifting and finding a new focus. The research I am continuing explores complex and fundamental questions of self and other-ness, something increasingly important to look at in relation to movement of people, freedom and understanding between different cultures.  I hope that in a very small way some of my work triggers some important discussions, not always comfortable for the viewer or the participant.

But all of this work costs money! If you can donate a little you will be helping to fund not only the travel to Finland but materials, postage, other production costs and exhibition costs once back in the UK.

The chance to work uninterrupted is priceless for any artist, but you can benefit from this period of work by receiving perks of limited edition prints, limited edition books and original new works which have not yet been publically shown!

The funding I'm  looking for is £1000. It will go towards our travel (by train and ferry... it's a three day journey via Hamburg, Stockholm, Helsinki then on up through Finland) and living costs in Finland, but also towards materials like paper and inks, plaster and clay for making moulds etc. I will also need to send work back at the end of the residency so this is an additional cost.

The perks for you will range from a set of postcards of new works, to limited edition signed prints to original sculptures and drawings. I want you to receive something really special as a personal thank you!

Here are just some of the perks you could receive as a thank you for your support:

Above: Some of the miniature pen and ink drawings from the 'Imagined Rocks' series, which will be made into limited edition prints and postcards.

Above: Some of the miniature pen and ink drawings from the 'Imagined Mountains' series, which will be made into limited edition prints and postcards (examples below)

And here are some of the other perks:

Above: An example of a porcelain pomegranate, slip cast and high fired, individually hand finished.

Above: An example and details of two of the 'Urpflanze' drawings (original size A1, print size A3).

Every perk will also come with a signed limited edition artist's book 'Gifts for Mother Mnemosyne' PLUS a handwritten personal thank you!

For more information about my work and these pieces you can go to www.giftsformothermnemosyne.wordpress.com or www.emilyjoyartist.com 

If I don't reach the full goal the money will simply go towards the costs of the residency, so every little bit of funding is really very appreciated. 

Previous residencies have provided invaluable time and focus for developing work. I'm not only an artist. I am a teacher and a mother. These other 'jobs' not only feed into but also draw upon my time for making work, so dedicated time for my practice is vital. Past residencies have resulted in projects including 'Mother Land' (Germany 2013) and the Arts Council funded 'Gifts for Mother Mnemosyne' in 2014. Most projects have involved invited speakers and I am excited to have the chance to once again bring further discussion and speakers to my home town where there is such a thirst for discourse and debate.

Any creative adventure like this is a challenge, but I feel like I am open to experience and to allow experience to shape the work made. There may be difficulties in travel, in translation, in cultural differences and in once again translating all that back to the UK audience. But I know the connections I make, the stories I collect and the work I make from those stories will be valuable.
 
And if you can't contribute financially then you can still add your support by sharing this campaign and spreading the word to anyone you know who may be interested!
Thank you!

story:
Subject: Help me publish my next book!

Dearest friends and art lovers,

 

Thanks to so many of you for your support of my first book, “The Art of ABC” (http://www.tashasbamboobrush.com/bamboobrush/book.html).  I'm writing to ask for your support on my new project, “The Art of 1, 2, 3...” which will utilize my Chinese brush paintings as counting tools for all ages.

 

I have decided to take a different approach to publishing the new book which will cost as much as $2500 from start to finish. My goal is to publish in the next few months.

 

So, I just launched a campaign on the crowd-funding platform Indiegogo to help defray the cost, and I'm hoping you'll be willing to pitch in. In return, you'll receive a signed book from me as a token of my gratitude. You can donate anywhere from $25 to whatever you are comfortable with--every little bit counts!  And, as you know, these book make great gifts for new families (for every $25 contribution you receive a book).

 

All of the money raised will go directly towards the cost of publishing.  Any extra will be used for the third book -- which is in the planning stages. 

 

Your support means so much. Whether or not you're able to support me monetarily, you can also help by sharing my campaign through social media and word of mouth--please direct people to the aforementioned link. Many thanks!

 

With love and appreciation,

Tasha

www.tashasbamboobrush.com
story_txt:
Subject: Help me publish my next book!
Dearest friends and art lovers,
 
Thanks to so many of you for your support of my first book, “The Art of ABC” (http://www.tashasbamboobrush.com/bamboobrush/book.html).  I'm writing to ask for your support on my new project, “The Art of 1, 2, 3...” which will utilize my Chinese brush paintings as counting tools for all ages.
 
I have decided to take a different approach to publishing the new book which will cost as much as $2500 from start to finish. My goal is to publish in the next few months.
 
So, I just launched a campaign on the crowd-funding platform Indiegogo to help defray the cost, and I'm hoping you'll be willing to pitch in. In return, you'll receive a signed book from me as a token of my gratitude. You can donate anywhere from $25 to whatever you are comfortable with--every little bit counts!  And, as you know, these book make great gifts for new families (for every $25 contribution you receive a book).
 
All of the money raised will go directly towards the cost of publishing.  Any extra will be used for the third book -- which is in the planning stages. 
 
Your support means so much. Whether or not you're able to support me monetarily, you can also help by sharing my campaign through social media and word of mouth--please direct people to the aforementioned link. Many thanks!
 
With love and appreciation,
Tasha
www.tashasbamboobrush.com

story:
“NOW” offers a unique installation experience, casting a sacred and mystical space within six monitors and four projections, including a projection on a pool of water! Coming to the rescue to provide a path through the madness are two over the top, comical, Goddess-like characters who animate “NOW”. The high fashion Valkyrie, medicine woman, Perspicacious and the skeptical, sarcastic haute Goth, Catharsis. Shot in stunning natural landscapes, these two characters are often at odds, yet aligned in their mission to inform, entertain and guide the audience through steps for personal transformation. 

“NOW” explores the nexus between technology, the natural world and humanity. It incorporates the idea that the writer and mythologist Joseph Campbell discussed, about an emerging global mythology. It expands upon this concept to include the emergence of a global mysticism, tying ancient practices to modern quantum physics and recent discoveries by DNA scientists.“NOW” embraces the concept that the microcosm affects the macrocosm, and so as we clean up our own internal environment we are also remedying the external one. 

"NOW" proposes that each of us matter individually, and together - we are a force!

“NOW” will premiere at SF Camerawork in February 2018; before being exhibited at other venues around the world.

THE ARTISTS

Monet Clark is a performance and video artist. She received her BFA from SFAI and also minored in Holistic Heath at the pioneering department at SFSU. She has trained in mind/body medicine, intuitive and energetic healing, and herbal and vibrational medicine. Her works have exhibited at The Kitchen in NYC; WP8, Dusseldorf, DE; SFMOMA; 18th Street Arts Center, Santa Monica; Krowswork Gallery, Oakland; RETHink Art Digital Festival, Rethymnon, GR; Rapid Pulse, International Performance Art Festival, Chicago; and more. Her recent video “Bunny Girl” (2016), which has shown internationally including with AVIFF Art Film Festival, Cannes, FR uses wry humor to tie environmental degradation to the suppression of the feminine, offering hope for humankind  - in high heels.

Watch the Trailer for Monet Clark's "Bunny Girl"

 

John Sanborn is an award-winning media artist whose work has been shown at every major museum in the world, and broadcast worldwide. He has exhibited at the Whitney Museum, MOMA, and the Kitchen in New York; the ICA and Tate Modern in London; and the Centre Pompidou, Videoformes, Bandits Mages and Gallery de L’Angle in France. He has created broadcast work for PBS (“Alive TV”, “Great Performances” and “Sesame Street”), Comedy Central (“Frank Leaves for the Orient”) and  His feature length media works have played at major international festivals including the Tribeca, Sundance, Mill Valley, Rotterdam, New York and London film festivals. He was an artist-in-residence at the celebrated TV Lab at WNET/13 and received grants from the NEA, NYSCA, and the Rockefeller Foundation. Vogue magazine called him “the acknowledged genius in the field”.

Watch the trailer for John Sanborn's "The Temptation of St. Anthony"

 

WHAT WE NEED TO SUCCEED

In order to create “NOW” we are seeking $12,000 to produce the video and install it at SF Camerawork in February 2018. SF Camerawork is also raising funds and only through our combined efforts we can make “NOW” a reality.

Productions costs include:

  • The creation of costumes for the two main characters. Monet’s practice includes building striking, wryly humorous characters through fashion pieces that provide ironic commentary.
  • We need to shoot on location, not a big budget with a huge crew, but travel is involved as the natural landscape is part of the overall message of the piece.
  • Renting a drone camera to shoot sweeping landscapes around California.
  • Shooting in Sanborn’s studio with a high speed camera, to capture movement and gestures that bring the ritual visually to life.
  • We need to hire 4 dancers and rehearse them to play the spirits of change in the work and we need to pay for their contributions.
  • We need to edit the piece, which involves animation and layering images, creating a mixture of spiritual and cultural references that represent the global mystic and mythological melting pot.

Installation costs include:

  • Renting monitors and projectors
  • Building frameworks for the installation, which includes a site for projecting on water

Every dollar you contribute will go into the work you will get to see and participate in once it’s installed at SF Camerawork – it’s an offering from us to the world and to you. 

WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR SUPPORT

We have unique and personal perks at varying levels of contribution. Its our way to thank you, and to get you involved in the work, just as the piece itself will invite involvement from the audience.

Each perk involves you in the creation of a new media artwork, which is directed at personal transformation in order to transform our global environment and global conditions. We feel passionately that people should support this work and that their support be returned via thanks and gifts.

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD

With your help we are going to create something unique and amazing. If you can contribute, that’s wonderful - and if you can help by simply spreading the word about this project, and getting your community to pitch in and/or making sure everyone you know comes to see the exhibition at SF Camerawork, those are all wonderful ways to help as well. 

Thank You,

Monet Clark and John Sanborn

story:
ART, RECYCLING, AND BURNING MAN

I am a Mexico City based artist transforming useless items, recyclables, and trinkets that would otherwise end up in the trash into art. I've created pieces that have been purchase by Greenpeace to be used as examples of how to transform trash into art. My art has been featured at galleries in Mexico and even Art Basel in Miami. Art has always been my passion and I have also worked as a film maker. I wrote and directed  a short film featured in 26 international film festivals, including Cannes. Some friends of mine asked me to use the skills and trinkets I've collected over the last 20 years to create piece of art for them to wear to Burning Man and I found a new passion! 

This is a piece of art done with electronic trash, bought by Greenpeace. It´s done with Iphones, cables, and the eyes of the skull are little cameras also from destroyed mobiles. 

I'm growing and adapting the skills I've learned from my other art pieces and the same collection I've been growing for 20 years. I started with a pair of sunglasses, then a hat, then three and I'm not slowing down. The more I read about Burning Man, the more I know my art belongs there - with you! Each trinket has the energy and history of the owner and the place were it came from. When put together in a certain way they can tell a story, a story I want to share with you. My goal is to go to Burning Man and deliver your perks to you on the playa. I´ll share  the story of the piece of art and the origin and history of the individual trinkets you are getting. Each one is unique and completely unrepeatable, composed of trinkets collected over the last 20 years. 

The CUSTOM perks include video chatting with me, exploring my collection virtually and designing a completely custom piece. The ARTIST'S CHOICE perks will be created by me with some very basic input from you (size, type, etc). Limited PROTOTYPE perks are the items created while developing my methods - these items may have visible glue or minor flaws from throwing the items around, wearing them and transporting them to make sure everything stays attached and the items are truly playa-ready. 

If you're not going to Burning Man - I'll be shippinng your perks from the US on my way to Burning Man. If you are going to Burning Man, I invite you to participatein a RADICAL RITUAL! Clean your drawers and bring your loved, unloved, forgotten, or treasured trinkets to LIMINAL LABS. I´ll collect them there, bring them to Mexico and make new compositions that might end in other hands. My goal is to go to Burning man to collect trinkets and other kind of small trash (MOOP!) and then bring them to my workshop in Mexico to transform them into art.

With your contibution I´ll pay for a Burning Man ticket (a friend is holding one), flights to and from Mexico City with lots of luggage, materials to do your perks and continue with my recycling and art projects. This also supports future art projects that I will produce with what I collect at Burning Man. If I don´t reach my goal, the funds will go towards fulfilling the perks (which my associate will still deliver on playa or ship from the US) and planning for next year. 

By supporting my campaign, you aren't just supporting an artist, you're helping the environment, recyclyng culture, and innovation with MOOP!

This are a couple links of my art and recycling work with Greenpeace Mexico:

https://web.facebook.com/greenpeacemexico/video...

https://web.facebook.com/greenpeacemexico/video...

https://web.facebook.com/greenpeacemexico/video...

story:
We are a family of stone sculptors.

And our trade is endangered.

In the only stone carvers guild in America, there are approximately 30 members.  The majority are past their 60's, and to our knowledge currently none of them have an apprentice.  

Stone carving and sculpture is part of the history of almost every culture. Stone is the most used material to hold the knowledge of human history.

This is worth saving.

As a family, it has been our mission to preserve this endangered art.  I learned the art of stone sculpting from a master sculptor in Ireland. This man taught me freely, asking only that I do all I can to keep the trade alive. Since that time, I have.

Preserving my trade has become my life's purpose. 

I've taught my children. I've taught free classes to people from all walks of life, changing their lives.  I teach at festivals, at universities.  

But we need to make this bigger.

And we have found a way.  

We are going to teach stone sculpture to 21 people, with the intention of those people to teach more.

This will create an immense wave of resurgence in this disappearing art.  

We will not be charging the students for this.

Why?

Because financial ability should have absolutely nothing to do with a hands on, life changing education.

Every day, we run into people that punch the clock, that work for corporations and chains that offer nothing but a paycheck. And many of these people are miserable.

On the other side of the spectrum are the handful that wake up everyday calm and happy, knowing that today, they're going to use their hands, and their minds, to create something beautiful.  And meaningful.  And lasting.

This is something so many more of us can have, if only given the chance.

With your involvement and support, we can make this possible!

And there's more...

This project is the start of something bigger.

This is a jumping off point for our ultimate plan of starting the only free school of stone sculture in America.

But to begin...

All we need, is to raise $4,000 dollars. This will fund all of the necessary tools and materials, safety equipment, building use, etc., to teach the first 21.

I have made a collection of 40 carved stone pieces priced at $100 each to fund this. You'll see we have many other perks for different donation levels.

If we raise above our goal, we'll just make this bigger!

With enough funding we can offer scholarships to bring people from outside the area.

With more funding we can begin teaching more artisan trades, like blacksmithing, woodworking, and glassblowing.

With support, this would become a world class artisan training center.

With your help, we could take this across America, traveling from town to town!

You may think, this is all really great, I'm interested in learning, but I have no desire to become a career artist, or professional sculptor. That's fine! These classes are designed to enrich lives even just for the pure enjoyment of a new skill!

So please get involved!

Even if you can't contribute there's lots you can do!

Tell all your friends, talk about our project on social media. Ask us questions! We love talking about our trade!

Thank you for reading, we look forward to hearing from you!

story:
ORIGINS OF OUR PROJECT
 
We are 10 Finns who met in the Sorin Sirkus youth circus Finland in the early 2000s. From there we scattered around the world to study in different circus schools and work as professional circus artists. We always had a dream that one day it would be great to work together again!
 
 
After having worked individually with for example Cirkus Cirkör, Cirque du Soleil, Cirko Aereo, NoFit State,  GOP Variety and multiple other small and large companies we decided to found our own circus company Sirkum Polaris in 2015. Together with another Finnish company Nuua we are now creating our first show ”Kulovalkea." Along the way we also found one South-African to complete the team of artists! 
 
We have spent already 2 years creating the show. So far we have had about 4 months of artistic residencies around Europe. The premiere of the show will be at the end of May 2020 in Odense in Denmark. 
 
 
WHAT DO WE NEED MONEY FOR?
 
We launched this campaign to have funding to buy costumes for the show. We are going to be 8 performers on stage and we are hiring a Finnish designer to design the costumes for the show. If we have extra money, we would use that to improve the scenography of the show. At the moment we only have the minimum of what we need.
 
 
This project is very close to our hearts. It is not just a circus show but a dream that we have been planning to achieve since we were little kids and now we are closer to realising it than ever! 
 
ABOUT THE SHOW
 

 

Kulovalkea is an old-fashioned Finnish word meaning a rapidly expanding wildfire, a metaphor to witness something visually beautiful and an opportunity to plant new trees.
 
The show will be a multidisciplinary contemporary circus performance with 8 artists on stage. It will hour and 15 minutes long. We have scenes built around tight wire, gymnastic balls, skipping ropes, dance triple trapeze, aerial rope, juggling, contorsion and acrobatics. 
 
 
Our starting point was to find something descriptive on all the circus disciplines that would connect them to every day moments and every day life. We wanted the circus to tell something by itself. 
 
The finished show will be a collection of fragmentes scenes that come together as a full experience. Through collaboration and confrontation, seemingly ordinary things turn into something unexpected and twisted. We seek a feeling that gets you carried away with the rhythm of detailed actions that are absurd and fun to experience, like an uncontrolled stream of conciousness. A very detailed, well rhythmic and disorienting experience of motion and mood.
 
 
EXISTING SUPPORT
 

The show wouldn’t be possible without the supporters we already have. We have received funding from Taike Arts Promotion Center of Finland as well as Subtopia in Sweden. This financing has helped us to buy the materials we need for the show, pay for the travels to residencies and allowed us to hire a director and light and sound designers.

We have had creative residencies at Cirko Center in Finland, Sorin Sirkus in Finland, Circa in France, Latitude 50 in Belgium, Subtopia in Sweden, Cirkör Lab in Sweden, La Roseraie in Belgium, ESAC in Belgium and Dynamo Workspace in Denmark.

 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
 
Origins and artistic process
 
Rather than focusing on technical virtuosity, the performance uses circus technics and equipment developed in a movement research to create tools of expressions as a language of it’s own. Various kinds of acrobatics, object manipulation and contemporary dance skills are used to create a world with its own non-sensical logic where things seem to work on their own, playful yet serious ways.
 
The audience is invited to take a closer look to the actions and details by technically bringing forward the sound, the breath and the pressure in the body during the intense movements. This brings forth the realism of the technical virtuosity of circus skills and enhances the genuine first-hand experience. The performance leaves a space for the audience’s imagination and everyone experiences the show in a different way.
 
Together these elements create a fragmentary contemporary circus experience that is played with a nonchalant presence. With minimalist aesthetics and carefully chosen focuses these elements create a performance with imaginative sceneries that turn into a colorful trip that is fun, virtuous and out of this world.
 
Creation calender
 
2017
  • September 2017, Cirko-center, Helsinki, 2 weeks 
 
2018
  • February 2018, Cirkör Lab, Stockholm, 2 weeks 
  •  June 2018, Subtopia, Stockholm, 2 weeks 
  • July 2018, Sorin Sirkus, Tampere, 2 weeks 
  • October 2018, Circa, Auch, pitching of the project 
  • November 2018, Latitude 50, Belgium, 2 weeks 
 
2019
  • January 2019, Cirko-center, Helsinki, 3 weeks 
  • August 2019, Sorin Sirkus, Tampere, 1 week 
  • September 2019, Circa, Auch, France, 2 weeks 
 
2020
  • February/March 2020, La Roseraie & ESAC, Brussels, 2 weeks
  • May 2020, Dynamo, Odense, Denmark, 2 weeks 
  • May 2020, Dynamo, PREMIERE

It will hour and 15 minutes long. We have scenes built around tight wire, gymnastic balls, skipping ropes, dance triple trapeze, aerial rope, juggling, contorsion and acrobatics.   Our starting point was to find something descriptive on all the circus disciplines that would connect them to every day moments and every day life. We wanted the circus to tell something by itself.  
The finished show will be a collection of fragmentes scenes that come together as a full experience. Through collaboration and confrontation, seemingly ordinary things turn into something unexpected and twisted. We seek a feeling that gets you carried away with the rhythm of detailed actions that are absurd and fun to experience, like an uncontrolled stream of conciousness. A very detailed, well rhythmic and disorienting experience of motion and mood.
  EXISTING SUPPORT 
The show wouldn’t be possible without the supporters we already have. We have received funding from Taike Arts Promotion Center of Finland as well as Subtopia in Sweden. This financing has helped us to buy the materials we need for the show, pay for the travels to residencies and allowed us to hire a director and light and sound designers.
We have had creative residencies at Cirko Center in Finland, Sorin Sirkus in Finland, Circa in France, Latitude 50 in Belgium, Subtopia in Sweden, Cirkör Lab in Sweden, La Roseraie in Belgium, ESAC in Belgium and Dynamo Workspace in Denmark.
 ADDITIONAL INFORMATION 
Origins and artistic process
 
Rather than focusing on technical virtuosity, the performance uses circus technics and equipment developed in a movement research to create tools of expressions as a language of it’s own. Various kinds of acrobatics, object manipulation and contemporary dance skills are used to create a world with its own non-sensical logic where things seem to work on their own, playful yet serious ways.

 
The audience is invited to take a closer look to the actions and details by technically bringing forward the sound, the breath and the pressure in the body during the intense movements. This brings forth the realism of the technical virtuosity of circus skills and enhances the genuine first-hand experience. The performance leaves a space for the audience’s imagination and everyone experiences the show in a different way.
 

Together these elements create a fragmentary contemporary circus experience that is played with a nonchalant presence. With minimalist aesthetics and carefully chosen focuses these elements create a performance with imaginative sceneries that turn into a colorful trip that is fun, virtuous and out of this world.
 
Creation calender
 
2017
September 2017, Cirko-center, Helsinki, 2 weeks 
 
2018

February 2018, Cirkör Lab, Stockholm, 2 weeks 
 June 2018, Subtopia, Stockholm, 2 weeks 

July 2018, Sorin Sirkus, Tampere, 2 weeks 
October 2018, Circa, Auch, pitching of the project 
November 2018, Latitude 50, Belgium, 2 weeks 

 
2019

January 2019, Cirko-center, Helsinki, 3 weeks 
August 2019, Sorin Sirkus, Tampere, 1 week 
September 2019, Circa, Auch, France, 2 weeks 

 
2020

February/March 2020, La Roseraie & ESAC, Brussels, 2 weeks
May 2020, Dynamo, Odense, Denmark, 2 weeks 
May 2020, Dynamo, PREMIERE

story:
Our Plea

COVID-19 almost brought Charm City to its knees, wiping out a vibrant nightlife and diverse food culture from Fell's Point to Hampden. Amid this pandemic, our beloved cat, Fattycakes, was stolen! 

The Queen only wants to feed the city she loves alongside the cat she loves. Baltimore deserves global street food in an eclectic atmosphere, so we're using Indiegogo to make the world aware of his catnapping. Think of this Indiegogo project as your virtual Truckstaurant without Fattycakes. 

Our fun way of keeping Gypsy's Truckstaurant alive until we find our cat and can celebrate in person again with the best city in the world!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're going to have a bunch of unique designs of Fattycakes available to our backers. We will have everything from limited edition t-shirts, and more exciting limited edition merch as our campaign progresses:

  • We're hoping to raise $7,500 by highlighting awareness of Fatty's abduction through fabulous designs including t-shirts and stickers featuring Fattycakes in every design until he is returned!
  • We are running exclusive, single run, limited editions of Fattycakes designs interpreted by a local artist and friend of the Queen. For each tier, we hit we are going to release an additional interpretation of Fattycakes to complete your collection!
    • Tier 1 (Limited to 250 prints)
      • Double Fatty Black T-Shirt with the hashtag #freefatty

 

 

  • All T-Shirts will be available in unisex sizes S-XL
    • Tier 2 (Limited to 250 prints)
      • Glitch Fatty with the hashtag #freefatty

 

 
  • This is our first campaign, so if you have any questions about your shirt, please email us or stop by the Truckstaurant (don't forget to wear a mask).
    • Tier 3 and 4 (Limited to 250 prints)
      • Werk Fatty with the hashtag #freefatty (design to be revealed if Tier 1 & 2 goals are met)
      • Double Fatty II with the hashtag #freefatty (design to be revealed if Tier 3 goal is met)

 

The Impact

Your contribution will help in the legal fees that may be incurred to bring Fattycakes home and support Fattycakes' castle, the Gypsy Truckstaurant:

  • We like to contribute to the city we love, however we can, whenever we can, in this case, bringing home a beloved Baltimorean feline friend
  • We are chefs and owners of the Gyspy Truckstaurant with more than 20 years of experience from Helen's Garden to present who are committed to our cat
  • Come down to the Truckstaurant and enjoy a drink and ask our pirate crew members about Fattycakes to learn more about our cat and his life with us

 

Risks & Challenges

The timeline for when we'll be able to reopen to full capacity is unknown at Gypsy's Truckstaurant and Gypsy Queen Cafe (you know that). We'll continue to do our best to keep you updated as the situation evolves. We've set the goal in the hopes that this ensures that the project gets funded but would love to surpass the amount we set (and who knows, maybe we'll add some cool stretch rewards!). All our clothing rewards will be printed locally. Please expect at least two weeks from the close of the fundraiser for the rewards to be printed, and to start being shipped. And of course, if for some reason these weird-as-hell times affect the delivery of your rewards, we'll let you know as soon as we do. Thank you for your patience and your support, Friends of the Queen!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We can all make a difference whether or not you contribute to the campaign:

  • Let people know about what we're doing and stop by the Gypsy Truckstaurant here in Baltimore (3515 Clipper Mill Road, Hampden)
  • Go to your nearest animal shelter and ask what you can do to help

story:
Becoming Unfinished

I am an artist and a learning & development specialist--with this performance installation I will combine my two passions and hope to nudge the world toward change.  Essentially I will create a gallery installation inside a theater with twice daily performances, November 20-24.  People can visit during gallery hours and use the theater to connect with the art and the space, and at 1PM and 7PM (the latter followed by a Q&A), they can see a 1 hour performance about father/son relationships, the continuity of human creation, and a comment on the current limitations of the human spirit.  When I'm not performing on stage, I will sit in the audience, watching the visitors look at the art, thus reversing the roles. 

My goal for this appeal is to cover the expenses of the space and production so that this exhibition is open and free to the public. 

For a very long time I've wanted to create a performance inside an art installation.  Soon after my father's recent death I saw a production of Our Town and became inspired by both events.  This exhibition will be a dedication to my father, to Thornton Wilder, and to the potential of the human race. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $10,500. 

  • $4000: space
  • $500: insurance
  • $1500: public relations
  • $525: onsite construction supplies
  • $1000: stage manager
  • $400: miscellaneous (printing, transportation, etc.)
  • $700: opening party
  • $1000: photographer/videographer
  • $875: estimated Indiegogo platform and transaction fees

By giving you will receive not only an invitation to the November 19 opening party, but also, for the following contributions:

  • $40:  Metropolitan Museum of Art entry & tour
  • $50: Guggenheim Museum or Whitney Museum entry & tour
  • $75: 8x10" c-print
  • $100: 16x20" c-print
  • $200: 20x24" c-print
  • $300: pastel nude drawing
  • $500: 16x20" or 20x24" museum quality fine art print
  • $1000: mixed media painting commission

 

The Impact

Leading up to the exhibition I will offer gallery tours to the surrounding community.  Each week I will curate a new selection of Chelsea galleries to visit and after we discuss what was seen, hopefully leading people to come up with their own insights.  It is my hope that the community be inspired to continue to use the galleries that surround it.  Although the galleries can be seen as elitist and are designed to be intimidating, they are a great free resource for inspiration, learning, and development.  Art has become this seemingly precious commodity.  But I think art can be as relevant as it once was when we were just starting out as a species.  The original art, cave drawings and carved images, were pure magic.  They inspired us to stay alive.   My hope is that art becomes as relevant now as it was then, not just a money making machine. 

These tours will then lead up to my own exhibition where I want to push people to move past their DNA, which has gotten our species this far, but how can we now pull together, cross tribal lines and move forward as a species.  How can we rise above what we were taught in school and by our parents, and our friends, our history and our stories, to come together  and create art that moves us forward?  To get beyond our past we have to share it--this is also one of the goals of this exhibition.  I want to inspire people to share their struggles, their pain, their calling, their victories.  We have to come out of our own closets, whatever those may be to us, be vulnerable and connect to the person down the street and across the world.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways to help:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about this campaign by reaching out to your network
  • I need volunteers to help out during the installation and during the exhibition hours
  • You can also volunteer your expertise--I need help with lighting, construction, and costumes.  I would much prefer to collaborate than do this on my own. 

 

Challenges

My biggest challenges will be working a full time job and creating the content for the exhibition.  The script is done and being scrutinized by professionals.  I will have a reading in October to test the material live, and although I have so much inventory (drawings, paintings, tapestries, etc.) I can use for the production, I want to create all new works to reflect what I came up with in the script. 

The other big challenge will be getting my body tight and ready, as the first third of the show I'll be shirtless!

story:
I have always taken a deep interest in pop-up books and am amazed by the combination of engineering and art to bring a story to life. My first large pop-up book creation had a circus theme and was made out of cardboard. That medium had serious limitations in terms of detailing and more importantly, longevity. Following that experience, my ambitions grew and I took the time to gather additional skills needed to truly bring about my vision. I learned to use laser cutters and CnC machines and am now building my new pop-up book out of wood.
The project combines woodwork, textile art, detailed painting, electrical work, programming lights and sounds. It is my most ambitious project to date.

What We Need & What You Get

I have received funding from Burning Man for this installation, which covers travel costs and a portion of the materials as well as Makerspace rental fees. I have also recruited several volunteers that are assisting with different aspects of the project. Additional funding is needed to hire skilled folks for specific tasks and to purchase additional materials for the project such as lights, a solar charging system, and a sound system.

My supporters will receive tokens of recognition for their contributions: wooden medallions fashioned on the same laser cutters used for the project. The medallions are mini books with the project title engraved. They can be worn on necklaces or hung from rear-view mirrors. Top tier contributors will receive a set of six wooden clothes hangers, engraved with geometric art. Select very supportive patrons will receive commissioned art pieces.

If I don't reach my goal this project is still a go! It just comes out of my very shallow, single mom artist pockets. I'm committed to seeing this project through! But with support I can push this project much further with more bells and whistles and more interactive pop-ups per page.

There are many challenges with the project. Making large scale pop-ups out of wood that will survive Burning Man. It is not something that has been done before. There is no “how to” for that.  If working for circus taught me anything, it is how to be resourceful

The goal is to bring an understanding of the strange and wonderful processes of metamorphosis. Do you know about the immortal jellyfish? Caterpillar soup? How these animals morph into new creatures? I learned a bunch of fun facts through this project and hope to share those with many.

There other ways you can help too! 
 

  • Talk about getting the project in a festival or art gallery near you. 
  • Coming to Burning Man this year? Come give us high fives and take a shift watching the book. It’s pretty strong, but it still needs minimum supervision to ensure festival goers aren't reckless with it.
  • Spread the word. We may just get enough momentum to make something big out of this project.

story:
Campaign Temporarily Close

Dear backers, we want to thank you for your support along the way. Due to some personal issue, we need to temporarily stop taking contribution. We will update you once we know when can we start again. We will also start an online shop in 2022, please stay tuned.   If you have contributed, no worry we will make sure you will get the perks. 

 

The Story behind DrainArt

DrainArt: enamel pins is a passion project by us. We are Mary and Philip, a couple living in Hong Kong and we love traveling to Japan. We love Japanese aesthetics. You can find surprises in every street corner. Fascinated by the beautiful manhole cover designs there, we think turning them into something wearable and collectible is a great idea. 

 

So we have selected 16 designs that we like best (with the generous help from our social media followers, thank you all!). We will turn them into enamel pins you can wear. We have also designed a wall scroll in the style of Ukiyo-e print to display all the pins on the wall.

Design Overview

 

All 16 pins will be 2 inches (5.08cm) in diameter, just big enough to recreate all the intricate details on the manhole covers. They are all soft enamel pins, the bases are finished with antique silver plating or black nickel plating. There will be two rubber clutches at the back on each pin.

A wall scroll to display all your pins

.A wall scroll in the style of Ukiyo-e print showcases the locations of the covers. The size is approximately 34x 82cm (13.4 x 32 inches) . It is a nice way to hang all the pins on the wall. It is a great decoration piece for your home. It will be printed on a high quality sturdy textured paper with a fine printing surface.

 A hand-drawn map of Japan indicates where the manholes are located

 

Add-on mini pins

To make things more exciting, we have turned 6 of the pins into mini ones you can add-on to your perks. They are adorable and is perfect to carry around. 

 

The 16 Manhole Cover Pins

Below is the list of the 16 manhole cover designs that we have chosen. They all are wonderful to look at and have very unique designs to reflect the history and culture of the locations. 

Otaru is a city and port in Shiribeshi Subprefecture, Hokkaido, Japan. It is a tourist spot famous for its historical building and a beautiful canal.

Tsuruoka ,is a city in Yamagata Prefecture. This manhole design depicts the beautiful building in Tsuruoka Park which is also famous for its Sakura trees.

Ojiya, Niigata Prefecture. Ojiya was the birthplace of Nishikigoi (special Koi fish). You can visit Nishikikoi no Sato, a museum for Nishikiigoi there.

Matsumoto, Nagano Prefecture. The cover depicts the colorful design of Temari, balls made from embroidery that are used in handball games

Shirakawa is a village located in, Gifu Prefecture. Famous for its historic house built in the style of gasshō-zukuri, Shirakawa is one of UNESCO's World Heritage Sites. 

Himeji is a city located in Hyōgo Prefecture. Himeji is famous for its white castle. The white egret orchid depicted on the design is a symbol of the city.

Miyoshi is a city located in Hiroshima Prefecture. The design depicts two cranes. The crane is the symbol of fidelity, welfare, beauty, sake, profusion, longevity in Japan.

Hiroshima is the capital of Hiroshima Prefecture. This design depicts senbazuru, a thousand origami cranes strung together. it is said that if someone folds a thousand cranes, they are granted one wish.

Tokyo Metropolis. This design is one of the most commonly found in Tokyo the capital of Japan. The design depicts a sakura flower surrounded by ginkgo leaves.

Atami is a city located in Shizuoka Prefecture. This design depicts a scene from the story of “Konjiki-yasha”, one of the best stories of Ozaki Koyo where the lovers say goodbye in front of a famous pine tree in Atami.

Fuji is a city in eastern Shizuoka Prefecture. This design depicts the beautiful Mount Fuji with billowing clouds and sea waves.

Another design from Fuji City. Fuji City has many places that bear a connection to the tale of the Princess Kaguya-hime, a princess that was discovered by a bamboo cutter inside a bamboo shoot. In this pin, you can the princess with the beautiful Mt. Fuji in the background.

Osaka is a designated city in the Kansai region of Honshu in Japan. It is the capital city of Osaka Prefecture. The design depicts the beautiful Osaka Castle.

Takamatsu is a city in Kagawa Prefecture. In this design, Nasu no Yoichi, who particularly famous for his actions at the Battle of Yashima in 1184 was engraved on a manhole cover.

Hiroshima is the capital of Hiroshima Prefecture. This design depicts beautiful maple leaves which is a common sight in Hiroshima.

Yamaguchi is the capital city of Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan. The words on the design are an excerpt from a famous Haiku Poem by Santoka Taneda who was born in Yamaguchi Prefecture. His statue is now shown in front of Yamaguchi Train Station

The Rewards

We are trying to keep the rewards tier relatively simple. We encourage you to get more pins by offering a better price per pins when you get more. 

All prices do not include shipping. When you back the reward, you will be able to see how much shipping costs.  We will use airmail with tracking from the post office. So it won't cost too much. 

The prices are based on Hong Kong dollars,  changes in the exchange rates on the day you back may affect the amount in US dollars.

Production

Although this is our first project as a couple. I (Philip) have expereiences in different kinds of product as I work as a advertising creative before where I gained connection to a network of printers. I am also an owner of a toy brand Classicbot. Classicbot's product line includes enamel pins. You can check them out here. My customers have been happy with the quality of the pins.I will be using the same pin manufacturer for DrainArt's pins. As you can see from the video below, the test sample from the factory is quite good already.

 For the wall scroll. We have been sourcing some sturdy textured paper with a good thickness. Below is a few paper samples. And we have done some test to see how well the paper is holding the weight of the pins. So we are confident that we should have no difficulty going to production.

There will be two rubber clutches at the back on each pin.A wall scroll to display all your pins.A wall scroll in the style of Ukiyo-e print showcases the locations of the covers. The size is approximately 34x 82cm (13.4 x 32 inches) . It is a nice way to hang all the pins on the wall. It is a great decoration piece for your home. It will be printed on a high quality sturdy textured paper with a fine printing surface. A hand-drawn map of Japan indicates where the manholes are located Add-on mini pinsTo make things more exciting, we have turned 6 of the pins into mini ones you can add-on to your perks. They are adorable and is perfect to carry around. 
 

The 16 Manhole Cover Pins
Below is the list of the 16 manhole cover designs that we have chosen. They all are wonderful to look at and have very unique designs to reflect the history and culture of the locations. 

Otaru is a city and port in Shiribeshi Subprefecture, Hokkaido, Japan. It is a tourist spot famous for its historical building and a beautiful canal.
Tsuruoka ,is a city in Yamagata Prefecture. This manhole design depicts the beautiful building in Tsuruoka Park which is also famous for its Sakura trees.Ojiya, Niigata Prefecture. Ojiya was the birthplace of Nishikigoi (special Koi fish). You can visit Nishikikoi no Sato, a museum for Nishikiigoi there.Matsumoto, Nagano Prefecture. The cover depicts the colorful design of Temari, balls made from embroidery that are used in handball gamesShirakawa is a village located in, Gifu Prefecture. Famous for its historic house built in the style of gasshō-zukuri, Shirakawa is one of UNESCO's World Heritage Sites. Himeji is a city located in Hyōgo Prefecture. Himeji is famous for its white castle. The white egret orchid depicted on the design is a symbol of the city.Miyoshi is a city located in Hiroshima Prefecture. The design depicts two cranes. The crane is the symbol of fidelity, welfare, beauty, sake, profusion, longevity in Japan.Hiroshima is the capital of Hiroshima Prefecture. This design depicts senbazuru, a thousand origami cranes strung together. it is said that if someone folds a thousand cranes, they are granted one wish.Tokyo Metropolis. This design is one of the most commonly found in Tokyo the capital of Japan. The design depicts a sakura flower surrounded by ginkgo leaves.Atami is a city located in Shizuoka Prefecture. This design depicts a scene from the story of “Konjiki-yasha”, one of the best stories of Ozaki Koyo where the lovers say goodbye in front of a famous pine tree in Atami.Fuji is a city in eastern Shizuoka Prefecture. This design depicts the beautiful Mount Fuji with billowing clouds and sea waves.Another design from Fuji City. Fuji City has many places that bear a connection to the tale of the Princess Kaguya-hime, a princess that was discovered by a bamboo cutter inside a bamboo shoot. In this pin, you can the princess with the beautiful Mt. Fuji in the background.Osaka is a designated city in the Kansai region of Honshu in Japan. It is the capital city of Osaka Prefecture. The design depicts the beautiful Osaka Castle.Takamatsu is a city in Kagawa Prefecture. In this design, Nasu no Yoichi, who particularly famous for his actions at the Battle of Yashima in 1184 was engraved on a manhole cover.Hiroshima is the capital of Hiroshima Prefecture. This design depicts beautiful maple leaves which is a common sight in Hiroshima.Yamaguchi is the capital city of Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan. The words on the design are an excerpt from a famous Haiku Poem by Santoka Taneda who was born in Yamaguchi Prefecture. His statue is now shown in front of Yamaguchi Train StationThe RewardsWe are trying to keep the rewards tier relatively simple. We encourage you to get more pins by offering a better price per pins when you get more. All prices do not include shipping. When you back the reward, you will be able to see how much shipping costs.  We will use airmail with tracking from the post office. So it won't cost too much. The prices are based on Hong Kong dollars,  changes in the exchange rates on the day you back may affect the amount in US dollars.ProductionAlthough this is our first project as a couple. I (Philip) have expereiences in different kinds of product as I work as a advertising creative before where I gained connection to a network of printers. I am also an owner of a toy brand Classicbot. Classicbot's product line includes enamel pins. You can check them out here. My customers have been happy with the quality of the pins.I will be using the same pin manufacturer for DrainArt's pins. As you can see from the video below, the test sample from the factory is quite good already. For the wall scroll. We have been sourcing some sturdy textured paper with a good thickness. Below is a few paper samples. And we have done some test to see how well the paper is holding the weight of the pins. So we are confident that we should have no difficulty going to production.

story:
House of Cards Project and the Sickle Cell Warriors

The purpose of this campaign is  to complete the House of Cards art project in order to raise money and awareness for sickle cell warriors. In 2001, my husband passed away from the complications of sickle cell disease at the age of 39 leaving my two sons, ages 7 and 9, and me with the legacy of a man who never gave up and made every moment count. He was a true warrior.  Before he died he became very interested in a new online community called the Sickle Cell Warriors (sicklecellwarriors.com).  He loved how they  focused on supporting those living with the disease with a positive never-give-up attitude as well as working for prevention and cure.

The House of Cards Project

The House of Cards project all started in October of 2012 when I wrote a poem for a friend who was in despair over a painful divorce. After writing this poem, I began thinking through my own loss and recovery and created what became the first "card" -- The Queen of Heart Transplants.


This then lead to the King of Hearts, titled The King of Pain and the Sickle Moon which explored my husbands struggle with the life-threatening and extremely painful disease.

One thing led to another and soon I was recreating the entire deck of cards as 26 x 40 inch mixed media works-on-paper. A book of poetry and art has also been produced with each suit and are available for perks for this campaign.  House of Cards: The Star Suit is currently in process.

The Heart Suit combines my personal story with Egyptian and Tarot images.

Clubs became the Tree Suit incorporating myth and story from different cultures with the artist’s experience of both the natural and symbolic world of trees. 


The diamond suit was became the Star Suit with a focus on celestial bodies and constellations and the way they are viewed from a variety of perspectives.

Finally, the spade suit is in the process of becoming the Bone Suit, with a focus on combining fossil prehistory with the Day of the Dead imagery.

Please visit my website, deniseweaverross.com to view all the images in more detail.

The Art Cards Campaign for the Sickle Cell Warriors

The purpose of this campaign is to raise the money to print the entire deck of cards. The profit from the sale of these cards will go to help fund the ongoing work of the Sickle Cell Warriors (sicklecellwarriors.com). The images have created a great deal of interest with over 2000 followers on my artist Facebook page and many people have expressed interest in purchasing the decks once the work is complete.

The Online Auction

The original 26 x 40 inch mixed media works-on-paper from the Bone and Star Suits will be exhibited at the Tortuga Gallery  in Albuquerque in October 2015. The Heart and Tree Suits were already shown in the gallery in February of 2014 and received much praise in the local media.

Albuquerque Journal Arts review
Sunday, February 16, 2014
Playing cards carry symbolism by Wesley Pulkka

Alibi
V.23 No.6 | February 6 - 12, 2014
Arts Feature
My Heart Is in the Trees
And under a giant sea bird
By Gail Guengerich

New Mexico Art Review, February, 2014
"Opening One's Heart"
by Chuck Lathrop

Simultaneously there will be an online auction for all the original pieces not previously sold. Any money over $500 (unframed)  or $750 (framed) will also be split between the Sickle Cell Warriors and the local Sickle Cell Association. The frames for these pieces cost $250.

Any monies raised in this campaign over the amount needed for the printing of the cards will go to these ongoing art making and fund-raising efforts.

story:
Project Summary

I have been working as a teacher in Baltimore City Schools for 15 years. At the same time, I have been an artist exploring spaces, objects and collections through photography. Starting in January of 2015, I was able to bring together my two worlds (urban education and fine art photography) through an iPhone photo project I originally shot and shared with friends via Facebook on a day-to-day basis. I began working on what was originally called the Stairwell Project when I was assigned to spend part of each school day patrolling a stairwell to ensure students were going to classes.  This allocation of my work time led me to reflect on the idea of "work," how spaces are used and time is parceled out in the context of the school building in a school system that, both physically and metaphorically, is crumbling around us and is in need of so much work. 

I began to collect images of the interesting and meaningful objects and spaces I encountered during each class period I spent on stairwell duty, and then extended that idea to also collect images on days when I was not stationed on the stairwell because I was covering classes for teachers who were absent when we could not secure a substitute or proctoring required state testing. While these images speak to the specific activities that occupy much of teachers' and administrators' time during the school day, they also point clearly to the work that remains for all of us who are invested in our public education system.  They are beautiful in composition and color but often disheartening in content: leaky windows, cracked concrete, litter, multiple layers of peeling paint, etc. These images point out the beauty in our crumbling system as well as the work that lies ahead. 

Side note: Please be sure to watch the video above in HD in order to get a full understanding of the impact of the imagery!

What I Need & What You Get

I am posting this project to raise enough funds to print a limited edition of 40 selected images from the Stairwell Project series. I want to put on an exhibition that showcases these images in hopes of sharing my experiences in Baltimore City Schools and helping our community better understand some of the challenges that our schools (and by extension our students and teachers) face. When you help to reach this goal, you will receive my undying gratitude and gorgeous art prints for your own home or office!

As a teacher and artist with a home, family and hefty student loan payment, I cannot afford to print these images without support from you: my community.  For those who don't already know how Indiegogo works, I do not have to raise the full amount requested within the 30 day fundraising period in order to receive the funds raised, so every little bit helps make the project happen. However, Indiegogo takes a larger percentage of the funds raised if I do not meet the stated goal. If you'd like to see this project completed, please share far and wide! Here is a detailed budget breakdown based on the full amount I am hoping to raise so you can see where the money will go. If the full amount is not reached, I will scale the project back accordingly by printing a smaller edition of prints if necessary. 

  • Printing costs for a limited edition of 10 prints each for 40 images (as quoted for archival quality printing on smooth fine art paper from a local printer): $2880
  • Printing and postage costs for thank-you postcards given as rewards (based on cost of $.50 per postcard, offering unlimited number but figuring based on 50 backers at this level): $25
  • Printing costs for unframed square prints given as rewards (based on cost of $1 per 4"x4" print, offering 340 square prints as rewards): $340
  • Printing costs for framed square prints given as rewards (based on cost of $35 per framed 4"x4" print, with finished size of 8"x8", offering 30 framed prints as rewards): $1050
  • Estimated shipping costs and shipping materials: $300
  • Estimated 10% Indiegogo fee: $460
  • Estimated total project cost: $5055

Please help me share these images and make them available to you and others.  Please share this project with your friends! Thank you so much for your support. 

The Impact

This project is the culmination of eight months of focused work taking and editing hundreds of photographs that might provide a window into the challenges Baltimore's students and teachers face because of weaknesses and blatant failings in our school system's infrastructure. The exhibition that will result from this fundraising effort will help bring the weaknesses in Baltimore City Schools' infrastructure in front of a larger audience of community members with the social and financial capital to push for real changes in the systems that are failing our community. The images in this project specifically focus on the spaces and objects that impact schooling and, in doing so, document empirical facts about the state of our school buildings and the learning environments we provide for the young people who will lead our city and our world. This project will push the larger Baltimore community to look closely at how we are failing our children, bringing issues of educational equity to the forefront.

Risks & Challenges

While I don't anticipate any major challenges in completing my project once funding is secured (as the funding for the project IS the major challenge I've faced), I know I will come upon small obstacles along the way to project fulfillment. I will need to secure a space for my exhibition, ensure the images I am working with are printed correctly and in a timely manner, and work with a variety of businesses to finalize the items I am offering for rewards as well as the space for the exhibition itself. Anyone who knows me knows that I am not a quitter, and I have a vast network of contacts to help me in making this project a success. If 15 years of ongoing work in Baltimore City Schools doesn't point to my ability to persevere in the face of challenges, I don't know what does. I have no doubts regarding my ability to make this project a reality and a success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help support my campaign by sharing it as widely as possible. It's as simple as that. Getting the word out goes a long way toward making this project a reality. Thank you!

story:
AN ARTIST LIVING IN LOS ANGELES NEEDS YOUR HELP TO KEEP HIS WORKSHOP. BASED IN K-TOWN WITH NON-STOP MENTAL STATE. 

KEEP ART ALIVE!!!

A small donation goes a long way and your donation can help a struggling artist stay in his workshop and keep working on new ideas.


 MONEY!  |  STRESS!  |  COLLECTIONS!  |  Top Ramen? | PROBLEMS. 

                                                                       

// As artist's sometimes we take chances. // I know first hand that life can be a risky tumbleweed of scares from a chance that we sometime's take. Well I have to admit, I'm not comfortable about the idea of life being scary at all! 

Personally as an artist, I struggle with the idea of taking chances in the first place. The biggest chance is job security. Do you risk it? Do you simply avoid the weeds of the financial tumble all together and stay complacent at a job that cares nothing about me and the craft that I produce? Or... take a leap of faith? and go Freelance? Risking the possibility of going down that long, dusty road called financial hardship.

             My art is always for sale, even if I have to sell it on the streets. 
Broke, Tired, and with no where to go. Having nothing you're craft by your side. The one thing you know is right and you've spend hours, day in and day out, trying to perfect. Only to find loose bits of work here and there from websites that allow these one off clients types that require URGENT! turnaround and compensate with mediocre pay? I'm fine with hustling for work, but the problem ends up that you produce great work, in their demanding urgent! turnaround time, and in return get the runaround for months on payment. You Place endless amount of calls, border line harassing them for what little dollar it was you contracted for in the first place. Only to be left with tumbleweeds. Throwing off your financial flow (what little there is left), picking up a dust wind tornado and pushing you further down that dusty road, consuming you with stress, hemorrhoids and buttful of MONEY! STRESS! COLLECTIONS! Top Ramen? PROBLEMS. I kinda like Top Ramen and I refuse to be JUST ANOTHER NAME to an employer. I know I am better that. 

         A small collection of what I've had to offer in the past. (all SOLD)

There is an invisible line that everyone stands in waiting for that "Dream Job" to come around. I believe we must make our dream job.  I live my dream job. I'm a hard worker and I know my worth. I refuse to let some temporary job attempt to evaluate that worth for me. Corporations in the work force are plain and simply not for me. As you can see I am not looking to hit some huge "Jackpot" with this campaign. Just some extra funds to help me get back on my feet for the month while I gain more client contracts and manage to get the never ending struggle back to somewhat of a better place.  

It's the first of the rent guys and the money is just not here to water my weeds. They are getting dry and  starting to tumble. I have been struggling lately balancing bills to sales and I am looking for a simple trade off. You can rest assured your donations are going to a good cause ... Money for art. 

I'll make u a custom piece of art depending on your donation. Also, You'll feel happy knowing that you are helping a real artist pave the way in his career. EVERY DONATION GET'S A PERSONAL "THANK YOU!" AND ANY DONATION OVER $5 GET'S A CUSTOM PIECE OF ART FOR YOU TO KEEP. 

   

   

        A couple more pieces of what I've had to offer in the past. (all SOLD)

ABOUT ME: I don't drink or do drugs. I've attached a couple images of my studio below so you can see where i work out of and that I aint' no bum. The video at the top of the campaign show's a little bit more about who I am. 

   

   A look into my small but functional studio, where all the magic happens.

As an Art Director I'm available to hire for any creative freelance work you might have as well. Please visit my website by clicking here to see how I can help you or your business grow. Like I said I'm not looking for a hand-out merely a hand-off and I truly respect the value of a dollar and hard it is to part with sometimes. You should know that your donation WILL NOT be used for anything besides living costs, supplies, and needs of everyday living.

"Thanks again for helping out a real struggling artist avoid the tumbleweeds of everyday life!" -Curtis David

 THANKS FOR EVEN THINKIN' BOUT IT! YOU ARE AWESOME!

"Thanks again for helping out a real struggling artist avoid the tumbleweeds of everyday life!" -Curtis David

 THANKS FOR EVEN THINKIN' BOUT IT! YOU ARE AWESOME!

story:
Short Summary

Friends, I have been so lucky this year. I've been granted the opportunity to visit Arquetopia in Puebla, Mexico for an instructional residency to study antique art techniques in a local museum. My most recent work delves into the creation of faux artifacts and utilizing refurbished elements to create sculptural objects, so I see this residency as an opportunity to deepen the cultural impact of the work and try to find new ways to approach the process using some new techniques and source material. 

I'm reaching out to my family, friends, peers, patrons and colleagues to support me in this endeavor to deepen my own creative experiences and networks, expand my tool belt of technical abilities and YES, fund a truly incredible adventure that I cannot financially handle on my own. 

What I Need & How You Can Participate

Here's a little more detail about what I need and why:

  • I need to raise funds to cover the residency fee ($1995), which includes room & board, instruction, meals, and some materials over the course of my three-week stay. Additionally, I need funds to travel locally and internationally ($450); to purchase local ephemera and materials ($250); to upgrade my camera equipment ($400; 55% self-funded), to purchase food and materials to fulfill my perks ($100); and to pay for shipping to get completed works back to the United States (estimated $200).
  • I'm offering a series of unique "perks" to get my community involved in the work I'll be creating during my residency. This is not your usual t-shirt, print and tote bag campaign–contributors will be investing in products that I generate and excavate, brief moments of cultural investigation, and community-oriented opportunities that directly impact in my residency experience. 
  • Because the Illinois Arts Council will be unable to fulfill grant requests in 2015, ifI don't reach my goal through this campaign I'll have to borrow monies elsewhere to pursue this adventure and make some compromises on the work I pursue during 

Risks & Challenges

I have already borrowed some money to cover the upfront costs to reserve my slot, but I will need to repay those debts and pull in additional funding for travel and expenses. Of course if I do not reach my goal, I could risk going further into debt and may need to make further compromises on the type of work I generate during my stay. This is my first international residency and I'm sure I will have many unexpected expenses to prepare for, but I am an avid traveller and feel confident I can navigate the landscape in a smart and safe way.

  • I have set up the perks so that they make an appropriate impact on my residency work and being minimally distracting from the core purpose of my trip. In other words, the thank-you gifts I'm able to offer are relevant, meaningful and simple to fulfill. 
  • If I can't pull in the amount of money I need I'll have to take out a credit card to cover these costs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still participate by helping me get the word out! Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in becoming a patron of my work.


Thanks!!
